I’ve looked, but it seems to me that we cannot change in Signal where attachments like images are stored.

I think that would be a helpful option to have. For at least two reasons:

  • If we can choose the storage location, we can have the files store on a (micro) SD card as well. That would help people whose phone already has a lot on it.
  • And then we can choose a storage location that matches our language. In my case, both Android and Signal use my native language. But the storage location is still called “Pictures”. That looks a bit odd since everything else is localised nicely.

(I’ve searched the forum and the GitHub issues, but couldn’t find a discussion about this topic.)

(Signal 4.18.3 on Android 7.0)

I like how WhatsApp has folders for media in /storage/emulated/0/WhatsApp/Media. With Signal already using a folder for Backups what if there were also folders inside of /storage/emulated/0/Signal for downloaded media. Nicely separated by the type of media and ONLY for media that has been downloaded not all media like WhatsApp. That way it would be easy to find downloaded files.

This feature would give Signal a huge advantage over WhatsApp - one of the most annoying things WhatsApp does is constantly fill your internal storage with media files, requiring regular manual moving of these files to a mirror location on the SD card - or deletion of the media files! If Signal simply allowed you to select the storage location and choose the SD card, it would have a rare advantage among secure messenger apps.

I would love to see choice for user to save the media directly to phone storage. It shouldn’t be a two step process of first downloading the media then Saving it. Some users like it the way it is but some don’t. We we get a choice how the media is stored(either directly or by individually saving them), then it would be a great addition.

I think this would be a major advantage over whatsapp and other Chat apps!
On a lot of Phones the Internal Storage is always full, so letting the User choose where to store Media Data would be very nice!
We already have the Settings for Data and Storage, even to manage Storage, where this Feature could be located.

Signal appears to be storing the media within its own database or at least within a private location within its app folder. This is secure. Unlike WhatsApp which makes the media available to all other apps.

Signal allows you to save media to an unsecure location. And gives you a warning about this when it does so. This is less convenience but it’s the typical convenience Vs secure trade-off.

You could allow for an option for all media to save to an accessible location and via a setting and warn the user then. But I would avoid this as I would say most users wouldn’t understand the risk they’re taking.

I personally think it makes sense to keep the filenames because that will keep them the same as on desktop exports, and more importantly because it is easier to find back where I moved files which I originally exported from Signal.

To clarify: if the name Signal is in the file name, I can search my files for Signal*.jpg and relocate any copies I forgot about, thus keep track of what I have exported and where I used it. That keeps me aware of the security aspect of exporting files outside if Signal as well.

I don’t consider the name Signal in the filename a potential metadata leak, because it can at best be used to identify someone uses Signal, which is not a significant piece of information.

In my opinion the filenames can stay as they are. I just like them to be exported to their own directory by default.

Discussion about the filenames should probably be continued in the other feature request linked a few posts back.

I agree with this request, and I also do not fully understand the intent of the current solution on Android. Pictures are currently stored to the generic /Pictures folder, with the naming scheme “signal-YYYY-MM-DD-time”.

However the /Pictures folder is also used by many other apps (e.g. for screenshots). If every app would behave like Signal does at the moment, then this folder would be a complete mess of various pictures from different apps, only distinguishable by their names but not by their location.

Therefore at the very least I second the request to change the default path to a dedicated
/Pictures/Signal folder. Or does the majority of users really think that the current solution of storing it in a generic folder is sufficient?

Completely agree, especially if Signal might support an opt-in auto save feature in the future, the user should have the option to choose where to save media, or at least have it saved at a more convenient location than /Pictures

posts.name: Unmovable Cheddar
posts.cooked:
This is actually becoming a necessity for privacy reasons. Starting from Android 11, usage of default storage root directories (like /Pictures) is limited. One key change is that it is no longer possible to create a .nomedia file that prevents images from being displayed in various media apps in any of the default directories that Android creates, including /Pictures. It is still possible to create a .nomedia file in subdirectories though.

So this means that you can stop images from being displayed in various media applications for apps that do not save in root /Pictures directory (Whatsapp, Messenger and virtually any other app) by putting a .nomedia file there, but you can never do this for signal saved images and anything you save from signal will be showing up every time you open any media browser or other app that displays images.

This turns “save” functionality into a privacy concern as you can’t prevent signal saved media from appearing everywhere.

I’m not sure if this is a bug or intended behavior of Android, but filed a bug report here just in case, if anyone wants to follow up on this further - Google Issue Tracker
